translated: The Causes and Conditions of the Transmission of the Dharma Treasury, Scroll 3

original: 元魏西域三藏吉迦夜共曇曜譯
analyzed: 元魏西域三藏吉迦夜共曇曜譯
translated: Translated by Tripiṭaka Master Kivkara of the Western Regions and Tan Yao of the Yuanwei Dynasty

original: 尊者阿難以法付囑商那和修。而告之曰。世
analyzed: 尊者阿難以法付囑商那和修。而告之曰。世
translated: The Venerable Ānanda entrusted the Dharma to Saṃghānandi and said to him:
The World-Honored One once traveled to Mathurā.
He entrusted me, saying:

original: 於此國中當有長者。🔽名為毱多。
analyzed: 於此國中當有長者。 名為毱多。
translated: 'In this country there will be an elder named Saṃgharakṣita.
His son will be called Upagupta.
He will be foremost in the meditation teachings.
Although he will lack the thirty-two marks, he will liberate beings just like me.
After my parinirvāṇa, he will bring great benefit.
The immeasurable beings he teaches and transforms
will all attain liberation and become arhats.
You should later ordain him and let him go forth.
If he enters parinirvāṇa, entrust the Dharma treasury to him.'
When Saṃghānandi was about to enter parinirvāṇa,
he told Upagupta:
The Buddha entrusted the true Dharma to Mahākāśyapa.
Kāśyapa in turn entrusted it to my teacher Ānanda.
Ānanda entrusted the Dharma to me.
I will now enter nirvana and entrust it to you.
You should diligently protect the eye of the world.
Upagupta said,
Yes, I will respectfully accept the teaching.
Then he spread the unsurpassed wonderful Dharma,
propagating the true teaching to save all beings.
His virtue was vast and unfathomable.
In the past he cultivated the unsurpassed supreme practice for a long time.
Although he was an animal, he always transformed beings.
He subdued the non-Buddhists,
erecting the great Dharma banner.
With the clouds of compassion he universally covered all.
Such merits and virtues will now be briefly explained.
In the past, the Bhagavān
was in Śrāvastī,
in Anāthapiṇḍada's Park.
At that time, Upagupta was a Nirgrantha,
named Satya.
His wisdom was profound and marvelous, and his debates were unparalleled.
He gave rise to deep arrogance and strutted around the world.
He wrapped his belly with copper sheets and placed a large fire on his head.
He said this:
I fear that my wisdom, which is full, will overflow to the outside.
For this reason, I wrap myself with metal plates.
The world is in darkness and cannot see anything.
I wish to illuminate the blind and the dark with my light.
I heard that the World-Honored Buddha is staying in Shravasti.
I want to go there to compete in eloquence.
Someone said to me,
If you see the Buddha,
your wisdom will be diminished and your light will disappear by itself.
I then went to where the Buddha was,
and said, Gautama,
I want to go forth and become a monk.

original: 智慧若與舍利弗等心則甘樂。
analyzed: 智慧若與舍利弗等心則甘樂。
translated: If my wisdom is equal to that of Shariputra, I will be happy.
If it is not enough, I will return home.
The World-Honored One said,

original: 假使汝積百千萬身。🔽欲望得及舍利弗者。
analyzed: 假使汝積百千萬身。 欲望得及舍利弗者。
translated: Even if you accumulate a hundred thousand or a million bodies,
you will never be able to catch up with Shariputra.
When the brahman heard this, he took leave of the Buddha and left.
Not long after he left,
the Buddha told the assembly,
One hundred years after my nirvana,
this person will attain arhatship.
He had the three insights, the six spiritual powers, and was liberated in the eight liberations.
His wisdom shone alone, widely transforming sentient beings.
The number of those he liberated was immeasurable.
The assembly, having heard this, gave rise to a rare state of mind.

original: 又復尊者於過去世那由他劫憂留茶山有辟支佛。
analyzed: 又復尊者於過去世那由他劫憂留茶山有辟支佛。
translated: Moreover, the Venerable One, in a past life, in a kalpa of the past, on Mount Urvala, there was a pratyekabuddha.
He was together with a group of five hundred of his kind.
The assembly of sages also resided on the side of the mountain.
Five hundred monkeys were on one side.
At that time, the leader of the monkeys
Gave rise to great faith and deeply cultivated the roots of goodness.
He always picked flowers and fruits to offer to the pratyekabuddhas.

original: 復於一時緣覺之眾端坐思微入于三昧。
analyzed: 復於一時緣覺之眾端坐思微入于三昧。
translated: At another time, the assembly of pratyekabuddhas sat upright, contemplating the subtle, and entered samadhi.
The monkey imitated them, sitting in the full lotus position.
Later, the pratyekabuddhas all entered nirvana.
The monkey passed by the flowers without taking any.
He pulled at their robes and pushed them, but they did not move.
He then knew they had entered nirvana and deeply felt sorrow.
He went to one side of the mountain and saw the sages.
He practiced great austerities, sleeping on thorns.

original: 翹足倒懸五熱炙身投巖起火。
analyzed: 翹足倒懸五熱炙身投巖起火。
translated: He stood on one foot, hung upside down, scorched himself with five fires, threw himself off cliffs, and started fires.

original: 獼猴即時收其灰棘除棄糞土牽足令舒。
analyzed: 獼猴即時收其灰棘除棄糞土牽足令舒。
translated: The monkey immediately collected the ashes and thorns, threw away the feces and dirt, and pulled on his feet to straighten them.
Then he sat cross-legged in front of him.
The sage saw this and thought it strange.
He then imitated the monkey's upright sitting and focused his thoughts.
Without a teacher, he spontaneously realized pratyekabuddhahood.
He then thought,
I attained the Way because of this monkey.
He then made offerings of incense and flowers.
At that time, the monkey's master was Upagupta.
Even as an animal, he was still able to awaken.
His aspirations were very sharp and his wisdom and eloquence were excellent.
When he reached Śāṇavāsin, he wanted to entrust the Dharma to him.
He observed that Upagupta had not yet given birth to a son.
He entered concentration to contemplate and knew that he had not yet appeared in the world.
He went with the bhikṣus to Upagupta's house.
Gradually, there were fewer and fewer, until he went alone.
Upagupta asked,🔽Why have you come alone?
Why are you alone?
He replied, Elder,

original: 我無俸祿有信出家乃見隨耳。
analyzed: 我無俸祿有信出家乃見隨耳。
translated: I have no salary. I left home out of faith and then saw him follow me.
Upagupta said again,
I enjoy worldly affairs and cannot leave home.
If you later give birth to a son, I will offer him to you.
Śāṇavāsika replied,
Excellent.

original: 後生一子名阿失波毱多。
analyzed: 後生一子名阿失波毱多。
translated: Later he gave birth to a son named Aśvagupta.
As he gradually grew up,
he went to ask for him.
Upagupta replied,
I have only one son. It is not right to give him to you.
If you give birth again, I will definitely offer him to you.
Later he gave birth to another son named Nanda-gupta.
He went to ask for him.🔽Upagupta replied,
Venerable One,
I now have two sons. I rely on them to earn a living.

original: 小者守護大子聚斂家業。
analyzed: 小者守護大子聚斂家業。
translated: The younger one guards the house and the elder son collects the family's wealth.
In this way, we can become very wealthy.
For this reason, I cannot give him to you.
If you give birth to a third son, I will then offer him to you.

original: 商那和修知其二子與道無緣。
analyzed: 商那和修知其二子與道無緣。
translated: Śāṇavāsi knew that his two sons had no affinity with the Way.
He also did not earnestly go to request them.
Later, he gave birth to a son with an upright appearance.
He was named Upagupta.
He was gentle, kind, and had a nature that loved compassion.
He was intelligent and eloquent, with a vast mind.
At the age of twelve, he was skilled in commerce.
Those who came to buy from him were always given more.

original: 商那和修觀其生未知優波毱。
analyzed: 商那和修觀其生未知優波毱。
translated: Śāṇavāsi observed that his birth was unknown to Upagupta.
He had already left the world for a long time.
He went to his place and asked him, saying:

analyzed: 汝今入市。 為當淨心。
translated: When you enter the market now,🔽is it with a pure mind
or an impure mind?
Upagupta said:
What is a pure mind and what is an impure mind?
He replied:
If the mind is united with greed and delusion,
it is called impure.
If it is not united with them,
it is then called pure.
He gradually used skillful means to teach him to focus his thoughts.
If evil thoughts arose, he should put down a black stone.
If a good thought arose, he would place a white stone below.
He would then concentrate his mind and not let it be scattered.
Whenever a good or evil thought arose, he would immediately throw a stone.
At first, the black stones were mostly many and the white ones few.
Gradually practicing, the white and black became equal.
When seven days were completed, his mind became pure.
The black stones were all exhausted, and only the white ones remained.
Śāṇavāsi thought like this:
Now, this good mind has been completely fulfilled.
The time has come to contemplate the path and to expound the Dharma.
He then expounded the Four Noble Truths.
At that time, he attained the path of stream-entry.
At that time, in the city of Mathurā, there was a prostitute
named Vasudattā.
She had many deviant charms, bewitching and deceitful.
She sent a messenger to the market to buy wonderful flowers.
The messenger then went to Upagupta's place
and obtained excellent flowers to offer to Vasudattā.
The woman, surprised by the abundance of flowers, asked the messenger, saying:
Did you steal these flowers?
The man replied,
I did not steal it.
I bought it at the market.
There was a person named Upagupta.
He was kind and magnanimous, and by nature loved fairness.
For this reason he obtained many flowers.
Moreover, this person had a beautiful appearance.
If the master saw him, he would never be angry.

original: 時婆須達遣人迎召。🔽憂波毱多都不許可。
analyzed: 時婆須達遣人迎召。 憂波毱多都不許可。
translated: At that time, Anāthapiṇḍada sent someone to invite Upagupta.🔽Upagupta did not agree at all.
Even though he was earnestly requested, he did not change his resolve.
There was the son of an elder who stayed with a prostitute.
At that time, a merchant came from a distant place.
He brought many precious treasures and sought to have relations with the woman.
At that time, the woman, greedy for his treasures,
killed the son of the elder and buried him in the house.
The family members searched everywhere.
They went to the prostitute's house and dug up the ground to find him.
They went to the king and fully explained this matter.
The king then captured the prostitute and cut off her hands and feet.
He cut off her ears and nose, abandoned her in a cemetery,
Upagupta thought,
He used his flourishing appearance to originally summon me.
For this reason, I stopped and did not go.
Now, for the sake of liberation, I should go and transform him.
He then took his attendant and went to the courtesan's place.
Vasudatta said,
I originally had a wonderful face and a beautiful figure.
At that time, you summoned me but were unable to look at me.
Now that you are already ruined, what use is it for you to come?

original: 答言姊妹我為觀汝實相故來。
analyzed: 答言姊妹我為觀汝實相故來。
translated: He replied, Sister, I came to see your true appearance.
I did not come for desire.
You originally used your appearance to deceive and confuse sentient beings.
Foolish people without wisdom give rise to inverted thoughts.
Now you should carefully contemplate this appearance.
It is impermanent, fragile, and like a mass of foam.
Covered with thin skin, it appears to be well-adorned on the outside.
Bones and sinews are connected, and it is filled with impure mucus and saliva.

original: 譬如畫瓶盛滿臭穢。🔽愚不覺知深生染愛。
analyzed: 譬如畫瓶盛滿臭穢。 愚不覺知深生染愛。
translated: It is like a painted vase filled with foul odors.🔽Fools do not realize this and deeply give rise to defiled love.
The wise understand this and will never take pleasure in attachment.
Using incense, flowers, bathing, and clothing,
Outwardly displaying adornment, inwardly truly impure.
The vast and deep great ocean can know the number of drops,
The faults of this body are extremely difficult to exhaust.
Therefore, the buddhas always rebuke it,
Never for a moment giving rise to thoughts of longing.
At that time, the prostitute's mind gradually opened up,
And she deeply gave rise to respect and faith in the Buddha's teachings.
She said, Virtuous one,

original: 所說誠諦唯願為我廣敷演之。
analyzed: 所說誠諦唯願為我廣敷演之。
translated: What you have said is true. Please explain it to me in detail.
Upāli then proclaimed,
All conditioned things are a heap of suffering,
Like a boil, like a wound, like an arrow piercing the heart.
Birth, old age, sickness, and death revolve without end.
Impermanent, decaying, unstable, and quickly decaying,
Like a criminal facing execution, with little time left to live.
Like a prisoner with no joy or delight,
Like a fruit on the road that is thrown away by everyone.
This body is despicable and will eventually return to destruction,
To be devoured by crows, magpies, foxes, and wolves.
The wind blows and the sun bakes, turning it into a foul-smelling, rotting mess.
Hair, teeth, and nails are scattered all over the ground.
How could such a body be something to enjoy?
You should diligently apply skillful means to seek liberation.
The prostitute understood and attained the pure Dharma eye.
After her life ended, she was reborn in the Heaven of the Thirty-three.

original: 優波毱多因觀諸法苦空無常。
analyzed: 優波毱多因觀諸法苦空無常。
translated: Upāli observed that all phenomena are suffering, empty, and impermanent.
At that time, he attained the fruit of the non-returner.
Śāṇavāsin then went to Upāli
and said to him,
You had a previous agreement to give me your son.
Now that he has grown up, can you give him to me?
Upāli was by nature greedy and stingy,

original: 貪其若此復不肯與。🔽尊者語言。
analyzed: 貪其若此復不肯與。 尊者語言。
translated: and he still refused to give him up.🔽The Venerable One said,
The Buddha prophesied that this person

original: 於百年後大作佛事饒益眾生。
analyzed: 於百年後大作佛事饒益眾生。
translated: will greatly benefit sentient beings by performing Buddha's work a hundred years later.
You should open your heart and give me this son.
Upon hearing this, Upāli then allowed him to go forth.
Śāṇavāsin took him to the monastery.
He then had him go forth and receive full ordination.
After the karman was completed, he attained the path of arhatship.
He was endowed with the three insights, the six supernormal powers, and the eight liberations.
He was skilled in speech and his eloquence was inexhaustible.

original: 心自念曰。🔽我於今者已覩法身。
analyzed: 心自念曰。 我於今者已覩法身。
translated: He thought to himself:🔽I have now seen the Dharma body,
But I have not yet seen the Tathāgata's physical body with its major and minor marks.
Having contemplated this, he gave rise to deep sorrow.
At that time, there was an old bhikṣuṇī
Who was 120 years old.
She had once seen the Tathāgata.
Upāli knew that she had seen the Buddha
And wanted to go to her.
He immediately sent a messenger to inform the bhikṣuṇī:
The Venerable Upāli wishes to come and see you.

original: 時比丘尼即以一鉢盛滿中油。
analyzed: 時比丘尼即以一鉢盛滿中油。
translated: At that time, the bhikṣuṇī then filled a bowl with oil
And placed it behind the door.
Upāli came to her dwelling place.
When he was about to enter the room, he spilled several drops of oil.
They greeted each other and then sat down.
He asked, Elder sister,
When the World-Honored One was alive, the bhikṣus
What are the proper ways of conduct and deportment?
The bhikṣuṇī said,
In the past, when the Buddha was in the world, the group of six bhikṣus
was the most crude and violent.

original: 雖入此房未曾遺我一渧之水。
analyzed: 雖入此房未曾遺我一渧之水。
translated: Although they entered this room, they never left a single drop of water for me.
Venerable One, you are now of high wisdom and excellence.
The people of the world call you the Buddha without the thirty-two marks.
Yet, after entering my room, you discarded several drops of oil.
Judging from this,
the people of the Buddha's time must have been truly wonderful.
Having heard these words, Upagupta
deeply regretted and felt extremely ashamed.
The bhikṣuṇī said,
Venerable One, you should not feel ashamed of yourself.
As the Buddha said,

original: 我滅度後初日眾生勝二日者。
analyzed: 我滅度後初日眾生勝二日者。
translated: the beings on the first day after my parinirvāṇa are superior, those on the second day
are even more inferior,
and in this way, their merit and virtue diminish.
They become more foolish, ignorant, and dull, and their wholesome qualities weaken.
How much more so for the Venerable One, who is a hundred years after the Buddha!
Even if you commit improper acts,

original: 正得其宜何足為怪。🔽爾時毱多而問之言。🔽姊見如來。
analyzed: 正得其宜何足為怪。 爾時毱多而問之言。 姊見如來。
translated: It is only natural, so why be surprised?

analyzed: 其事云何。 比丘尼曰。
translated: At that time, Upagupta asked, Sister, what was it like when you saw the Tathāgata?

original: 昔佛在世我年二十始欲行嫁。
analyzed: 昔佛在世我年二十始欲行嫁。
translated: The bhikṣuṇī said, In the past, when the Buddha was in the world, I was twenty years old and was about to get married.
I lost a golden hairpin that fell into deep grass.
I searched for it but could not find it.
I then used lamps and candles to search everywhere for it.
I searched until I was exhausted, but could not find it.
Just then, the Tathāgata was traveling and passing by.
His golden light was radiant, like a hundred thousand suns.
In dark places, it was all greatly illuminated.
Even the most subtle things were all revealed.
I then found my hairpin and took it.
For this reason, I was able to see the Buddha.
When Upagupta heard this,

original: 倍生悲戀歎未曾有。🔽商那和修即告之曰。
analyzed: 倍生悲戀歎未曾有。 商那和修即告之曰。
translated: he felt even more grief and admiration, saying it was unprecedented.
Śāṇavāsin then told him, The Buddha prophesied that a hundred years after him,
you would be foremost in sitting meditation and greatly transform sentient beings.
Now is the right time.

original: 宜作饒益令諸群生服甘露味。
analyzed: 宜作饒益令諸群生服甘露味。
translated: It is fitting to bring benefit and cause all beings to imbibe the flavor of the sweet dew.
Upagupta said,
Yes, I will follow your instructions.
In the country of Mathura, he gathered a great assembly.
Like sitting for a half-month, he expounded the Dharma.

original: 所謂施論戒論生天之論。
analyzed: 所謂施論戒論生天之論。
translated: Namely, the discourses on giving, morality, and rebirth in the heavens.
Desire is impure, and liberation is supreme.
King Mara Paplyas then became worried and fearful.
And thought like this:
Upagupta has gathered a great assembly.
He will surely teach them to leave my realm.
I will now go and destroy their minds.
When he was expounding the Dharma, he rained down real gold and jewels.
Or rained down flowers, necklaces, and bright and pure light.
He transformed into a white elephant adorned with the seven treasures.
He appeared as a woman, extremely beautiful and extraordinary.
The entire assembly watched and had no mind to listen to the Dharma.
For three days, he expounded the profound flavor of the Dharma.
Not a single person attained the Way.
King Mara rejoiced and deeply congratulated himself.
Upagupta then entered samādhi.
He contemplated and observed who had done this.

original: 魔王復以真珠花瓔著其頸上。
analyzed: 魔王復以真珠花瓔著其頸上。
translated: The Māra king again put a pearl flower necklace around his neck.
The Venerable one then observed and knew it was the Māra's doing.
He then had this thought.
The evil Māra is jealous and harmful, corrupting the true Dharma.
Why did the Tathāgata not subdue him?
He then observed the Buddha's mind and made him transform.
He then used three corpses.
Namely, a snake, a dog, and a human.
He transformed them into a flower garland and moved the Māra to come.
And said to him,
You gave me a garland, deeply recognizing and generously giving.
Now I will return it to you as a token of my gratitude.
The Māra was greatly delighted and stretched his neck to receive it.

original: 至其頸已還見死屍虫蛆欲出臭爛難近。
analyzed: 至其頸已還見死屍虫蛆欲出臭爛難近。
translated: When it reached his neck, he saw the dead bodies, maggots about to emerge, and the stench was unbearable.
The Māra saw this and deeply felt disgust.
He said to Upagupta,

original: 汝今云何以斯死屍繫吾頸耶。
analyzed: 汝今云何以斯死屍繫吾頸耶。
translated: Why do you now bind these dead bodies around my neck?
The Venerable one replied,
A bhikṣu should not adorn you with flower garlands.
You put it on me with evil thoughts.
Now I put this stinking corpse on you.
This is just right.
You should not be angry.
The demon used his spiritual powers to try to remove the corpse.
It was like Mount Sumeru, immovable.
He became very angry and jumped into the sky.
He went to the heavenly beings to ask them to untie the dead body.
The heavenly beings all said:
This was done by the great sage.
We are ordinary and weak, how could we remove it?
He then went to the Brahma King to ask to be freed from the corpse bonds.
The Brahma King replied:
The spiritual powers created by the disciple of the One with Ten Powers.
I am now ordinary and lowly, how could I untie it?
Even if the eon were to burn and the violent wind were to swirl,
It would not be able to escape the bonds of this dead body.

original: 寧以藕絲懸須彌山欲脫此屍。
analyzed: 寧以藕絲懸須彌山欲脫此屍。
translated: It would be possible to hang Mount Sumeru with lotus fibers, but to untie this corpse,
There is no such possibility.
Just as one falls to the ground and then supports oneself to get up,
If you take refuge in Upagupta,
then this corpse-binding can be untied.
At that time, Mara accepted the Brahma King's teaching,
removed his arrogant mind, and deeply gave rise to respect and faith.
He went to where the Venerable One was, prostrated with his five limbs on the ground,
and said, Great Virtuous One,
when the Buddha first attained enlightenment and sat under the king of trees,
I led my officials and attendants to go and surround him.
From then on, the disturbances were countless.
Not a single bad word was spoken, yet I was seen as being slighted and humiliated.
The great compassion is vast like Mount Sumeru.

original: 汝阿羅漢少慈忍力。🔽於天人前而見𣣋毀憂波毱多答言。
analyzed: 汝阿羅漢少慈忍力。 於天人前而見𣣋毀憂波毱多答言。
translated: You Arhats have little compassion and power of forbearance.
In front of the heavenly beings, you see Upagupta as being despised. Upagupta replied, Mara,
you are greatly foolish and lack wisdom.
Using a Sravaka to compare to a Tathagata,
wanting to use a mustard seed to equal Mount Sumeru,
the light of a firefly to be equal to the sun and moon,
the water in a cow's hoofprint to be the same as the vast ocean,
the Tathagata's great compassion is not possessed by the two vehicles.
For this reason, we do not retaliate against each other.
Now, I am narrow-minded, with little compassion and forbearance.
For this reason, we insult each other.

original: 又復如來欲使我後降伏於汝。
analyzed: 又復如來欲使我後降伏於汝。
translated: Moreover, the Tathāgata wants me to subdue you later.
You will respect and believe in the Buddha because of this.
Because of this wholesome mind, you will not fall into the three evil destinies.
You will wash away the defilements and destroy all evil karma.
When the demon heard this, he was overjoyed.
His body hair stood on end and he felt unprecedented joy.
He said, Virtuous one,
because of you, I have given rise to a respectful and faithful mind.
You have greatly benefited me.
Now, please show me how to untie these three corpses.
The Venerable One replied,
You must not disturb the true Dharma again.
Only then will I untie them for you.
The demon said he would follow the instructions.
The Venerable One said again,
I have not seen the Tathāgata's physical body.

original: 汝昔曾覩宜為我現。🔽魔言。
analyzed: 汝昔曾覩宜為我現。 魔言。
translated: Since you have seen it before, you should show it to me.
The demon said, Virtuous one,

original: 我現佛身勿為吾禮。🔽憂波毱言。
analyzed: 我現佛身勿為吾禮。 憂波毱言。
translated: Do not bow to me when I appear in the form of a Buddha.
Upagupta said, I will do as you say.
He then untied the three corpses.
The demon entered the forest and transformed his body to resemble the Buddha,

He transformed into a monk, surrounded by disciples in front and behind,

He single-mindedly observed and spoke a verse, saying:

original: 咄哉無常　　無悲愍心　　能壞如是
analyzed: 咄哉無常　　無悲愍心　　能壞如是
translated: Alas! Impermanence, with no compassion or pity, can destroy such a

original: 上妙色身憂波毱多一心瞻仰目不暫捨。

translated: supreme and wonderful physical form. Upagupta single-mindedly gazed at him, never taking his eyes off for a moment.
He inwardly felt overjoyed and spoke a verse in praise, saying:

original: 快哉清淨業　　能成是妙果
analyzed: 快哉清淨業　　能成是妙果

original: 非自在天生　　亦非無因作
analyzed: 非自在天生　　亦非無因作

original: 面如紫金色　　目淨如青蓮
analyzed: 面如紫金色　　目淨如青蓮
translated: The face is like purple gold in color, and the eyes are pure like blue lotus flowers.

original: 端政超日月　　奇妙勝華林
analyzed: 端政超日月　　奇妙勝華林
translated: His handsomeness surpasses the sun and moon, his wondrousness surpasses the flower forest.

original: 湛然若大海　　不動如須彌
analyzed: 湛然若大海　　不動如須彌
translated: Tranquil like the great ocean, unmoving like Mount Sumeru.

original: 安步猶師子　　顧視同牛王
analyzed: 安步猶師子　　顧視同牛王
translated: Walking steadily like a lion, looking around like the king of oxen.

original: 無量百千劫　　淨修身口意
analyzed: 無量百千劫　　淨修身口意

original: 以是故獲得　　如此殊妙身
analyzed: 以是故獲得　　如此殊妙身
translated: For this reason, he attained such an extraordinary and wondrous body.

original: 怨見尚歡喜　　況我不欣慶
analyzed: 怨見尚歡喜　　況我不欣慶
translated: Even enemies see him and are delighted, let alone me not rejoicing.
After Upagupta spoke this verse,
he contemplated the Buddha's mind and suddenly felt like bowing in respect.
Mara said, Virtuous one,
why are you like this?
He replied, Mara,
I know that the World-Honored One has long since entered nirvana.
Seeing this appearance is like seeing the Buddha.
The joy arising within is why I bow.
Mara returned to his original form and went back to the heavens.
On the fourth day, Mara came down again.
With a loud voice, he proclaimed to all,
All of you,
if you wish to attain wealth, happiness, and rebirth in the human and heavenly realms,
Wishing to seek nirvana, the supreme peace and bliss.
Not seeing the Tathāgata's great compassion in expounding the Dharma.
All should go to Upāli's place.
Listen and accept the wonderful Dharma, practice it with utmost sincerity.
At that time, the men and women, young and old, of the city of Mathurā.
Heard that the Venerable One had subdued the evil Māra.
Hundreds of thousands and millions of people all gathered like clouds.
Upāli ascended the lion seat.
According to their capacities, he expounded various kinds of Dharma.
Hundreds of thousands of beings attained the path of stream-entry.
Eighteen thousand people became arhats.
From then on, the number of those he transformed was immeasurable.
For King Aśoka, he brought about great benefit.
That king's merits and virtues were profound and far-reaching, surpassing others.
He attained unshakable faith in the Three Jewels.
Because of his wholesome causes, he attained this supreme fruit.

original: 昔佛住在迦蘭陀林日時已到將諸比丘入城乞食。
analyzed: 昔佛住在迦蘭陀林日時已到將諸比丘入城乞食。
translated: In the past, when the Buddha was dwelling in the Kalandaka Bamboo Grove, it was time to go into the city to beg for alms, so he took the bhikṣus with him.
On the way, he saw two boys.
One was named Devashena.
The other was named Ashenashena.
They built cities, houses, and granaries.
They also named the rice, millet, hemp, and wheat.
They then gathered and stored them in the granaries.
The Tathagata's light illuminated everything.
They all became the same golden color, without any impurity.

original: 德勝歡喜探名󰉓者奉獻如來。
analyzed: 德勝歡喜探名󰉓者奉獻如來。
translated: Devashena joyfully took the flour and offered it to the Tathagata.
Because his body was small, he could not reach.
Ashenashena knelt down and lifted him up to offer it.
Then the World-Honored One
smiled slightly.
At that time, Ananda immediately said to the Buddha,
For what reason did the Tathagata show this smile?
The Buddha told Ananda,
Do you see these two boys?
Yes, I see them.
These two boys,
one hundred years after me,
will become one-fourth of a wheel-turning king.
In the city of Vaisali, they will rule the world with the right Dharma.
They will distribute my relics everywhere.
He built 84,000 jeweled stupas.
He then gave this land to Ānanda.
If it is applied to the south wall of the room, it will be completely covered.
After a hundred years, he indeed became a king.
He was tyrannical and evil, killing many people.
He built a prison city called Delightful Outside.
He appointed an evil man named Ji-li.
He set up a large boiling cauldron, iron balls, swords and knives.
Such things were fully prepared.
Those who came from outside were all punished for their crimes.
There was a son of a wealthy family who left home to become a monk.

original: 遊行乞食入愛樂獄尋欲還出。
analyzed: 遊行乞食入愛樂獄尋欲還出。
translated: He went begging for food and entered the prison of Delight. He wanted to leave immediately.
Ji-li stopped him.
He then raised his voice and cried out loudly.
The jailer asked,
Why are you like this?
The monk replied,
I am not afraid of death, but it is a good opportunity.
I have just left home and have not yet realized the taste of the Way.
The human body is difficult to obtain and the Buddha's teachings are difficult to encounter.
Now that I have encountered them, I will die in vain.
Thinking of this, he wept with great compassion.
Jīrika replied,
The king has previously decreed that
those who enter this prison will never be allowed to leave.
The bhikṣu said again,

original: 我今定死願赦七日當就刑戮。
analyzed: 我今定死願赦七日當就刑戮。
translated: I will now certainly die. Please pardon me for seven days and then I will face the execution.
At that time, the prison guards immediately allowed it.
In King Aśoka's palace, the palace women
were teasing and joking with other men.

original: 王大瞋怒付獄治罪。🔽尋以鐵杵碎之如塵。
analyzed: 王大瞋怒付獄治罪。 尋以鐵杵碎之如塵。
translated: The king became very angry and sent them to prison to be punished.🔽They were immediately crushed to dust with an iron pestle.
Their bones and flesh were scattered like foam.
The bhikṣu, having observed this, deeply felt disgust.
He then sighed and said,
Indeed, the words of great compassion are true.
It is said that form is impermanent, like a bubble or a flame.
It is not firm, quickly decays, and is very difficult to preserve.
Previously, this woman's appearance was radiant.
Now, if I were to seek her again, where would she be?
Human life is false and deceptive, with nothing to protect it.
Nobility, poverty, foolishness, and wisdom are not the same.
Although there are differences in birth, all have this death.
It is like the springs and sources of the hundred rivers each being different.
There is not a single stream that does not enter the great ocean.
People are also like this, all heading towards the place of death.
According to the length of their karma, they receive life for a long or short time.
Before long, they will also return to extinction.
This body is foul-smelling, impure, and disgusting.
The thin skin covers it up, falsely giving rise to thoughts of affection.
One does not observe the various faults within it.
Alas! Birth and death are what fools are fond of.
This is not where sages and saints delight in and become attached to.
Observing in this way, from night until dawn,
One then cuts off the various bonds and attains the stage of stream-entry.
Turning to be even more diligent, one attains the path of arhatship.
After seven days, Jīrika said,
Your time is up now, you can go to your execution.
The bhikṣu replied,
My night has passed and my day has dawned.
What is to be done has been done, you may punish me as you see fit.
Jīrika became angry and put him in a cauldron to boil.
The raging flames became even cooler.
He found it strange and went to the cauldron to observe.
He saw a thousand-petaled lotus flower growing in the cauldron,
with the bhikṣu sitting cross-legged upon it.
At that time, Giri went to report to the king.
The king, together with his retinue, came to observe.

original: 於是比丘踊身虛空作十八變。🔽王見斯事歎未曾有。
analyzed: 於是比丘踊身虛空作十八變。 王見斯事歎未曾有。
translated: Then the bhikṣu rose into the sky and performed the eighteen transformations.
The king, seeing this, marveled at it and said:
We are now the same in having a human form.
The difference in majestic virtue and wonder is so great.
I have not yet understood.
I only wish you would explain it.
At that time, the bhikṣu, wanting to transform the king,
said this:
I have severed the bonds and am liberated from the three existences.
Free from all agitation, I am peacefully and happily at ease.
Great king, you should know that.
The Buddha prophesied for you that
a hundred years later, in the city of Hwa,
you will distribute the relics and widely establish jeweled stupas.
Why are you now committing this evil?
And had no compassion for sentient beings.
The king should now fulfill the Buddha's intention.
And bestow the joy of fearlessness upon sentient beings.
Having heard this, the king deeply repented.
He took refuge in the Three Jewels and gave rise to a respectful and faithful mind.
He collected the meritorious relics of the Tathāgata.
And built eighty-four thousand jeweled stupas.
After completing the stupas, he went to the Kukkutārāma monastery.
He joined his palms and asked the elder Yaśas,

original: 此閻浮提頗有如我受記者不。
analyzed: 此閻浮提頗有如我受記者不。
translated: Is there anyone in this Jambudvīpa who has received a prophecy like me?
Yaśas replied,
The Buddha prophesied that Venerable Upagupta
would bring great benefit a hundred years later.
The king asked again,
Has that pure person appeared in the world yet?
He replied, Great King,
he was born long ago and attained arhatship.
He is teaching the Dharma surrounded by disciples on Mount Urumunda.
The king then prepared to go and pay homage.
He immediately sent a messenger
to say to the great sage,
King Aśoka wanted to come and pay respects.
The Venerable One thought to himself:
This place is cramped and cannot accommodate many people.
I should go to him myself now.
He then put on his robes and went to the city of Pāṭaliputra.
When the king heard this, he was delighted and swept and cleaned the streets.
He burned incense, scattered flowers, and played various kinds of music.
He then went out with his ministers to welcome the Venerable One.
When he saw him, he prostrated himself on the ground with his whole body.
He gazed up at him with utmost sincerity, never taking his eyes off him for a moment.
He said, Great Sage,
I have become a king, with freedom and happiness,
but it is not as good as seeing you today.
My heart is filled with great joy. He then spoke a verse, saying:

original: 佛雖入寂定　　尊今補處生
analyzed: 佛雖入寂定　　尊今補處生
translated: Although the Buddha has entered quiescent concentration, the Venerable One has been born in his place.

original: 今應見教勅　　我當隨順學
analyzed: 今應見教勅　　我當隨順學
translated: You should now show and teach, and I will follow and learn.
Then the Venerable One,
with his hand, stroked the king's head.
He replied in verse, saying:

original: 謹慎恐怖莫放逸　　王位富貴難可保
analyzed: 謹慎恐怖莫放逸　　王位富貴難可保
translated: Be careful and fearful, do not be negligent, the wealth and nobility of the king's position are difficult to preserve.

original: 一切皆當歸遷滅　　世間無有常住者
analyzed: 一切皆當歸遷滅　　世間無有常住者
translated: All will eventually return to change and extinction, there is no permanence in the world

original: 三寶難遭汝今遇　　恒當供養莫休廢
analyzed: 三寶難遭汝今遇　　恒當供養莫休廢
translated: The Three Jewels are difficult to encounter, you have now met them, you should always make offerings and not neglect them.

original: 爾時阿恕伽王即請尊者入於宮內。
analyzed: 爾時阿恕伽王即請尊者入於宮內。

He personally helped him up to a jeweled seat.

The Venerable One praised him, saying,

original: 善哉善哉我今當往盡示王處。
analyzed: 善哉善哉我今當往盡示王處。
translated: Excellent, excellent! I will now go and show you all the places.

original: 向林微尼園示佛生處乃至復詣拘尸那城化緣訖已入涅槃處。
analyzed: 向林微尼園示佛生處乃至復詣拘尸那城化緣訖已入涅槃處。
translated: He went to the Lumbini Grove and showed him the place of the Buddha's birth, and then further went to the city of Kuśinagara, where the Buddha completed his transformative work and entered nirvāṇa.
When the king heard these words, he fainted and fell to the ground.
Cold water was sprinkled on his face and only then did he regain consciousness.
Then stūpas were built at all those places.
He donated a hundred thousand ounces of gold and then left.

original: 復更示王舍利弗等五百羅漢功德之塔。
analyzed: 復更示王舍利弗等五百羅漢功德之塔。

What merits does this stupa have?
He replied, Great king,

original: 乃往過去九十一劫毘婆尸佛滅度之後。
analyzed: 乃往過去九十一劫毘婆尸佛滅度之後。
translated: In the past, ninety-one kalpas ago, after the parinirvāṇa of Vipaśyin Buddha,
Bakkula lived in a certain monastery.
He saw the wealthy and noble coming to make offerings to the saṅgha.
The Venerable one was drunk and sleeping at that time.
He thought to himself,
Since I am poor, what can I offer?
I now have only one āmalaka fruit.

original: 眾僧若有病患之者可以施之。
analyzed: 眾僧若有病患之者可以施之。
translated: If there are any sick monks in the saṅgha, I can give it to them.
Use it to cure their illnesses.

He asked the pharmacist for an āmalaka fruit.
The pharmacist said,
There is someone who will give you medicine. You can take it and recover.
At that time, the bhikṣu went to get the medicine.
After taking it, his illness was cured.

original: 由是緣故九十一劫生人天中。
analyzed: 由是緣故九十一劫生人天中。

The flames were blazing, and she covered him with ashes.

He found his son in the oven.
Later, at another time, his stepmother was cooking meat again.
The young child went to ask for some again.
His stepmother became even angrier and threw him into the cauldron.
The water was boiling hot, but it did not burn or scald him.
His father searched for him again but could not find him.
He said this:
Where is my son now?
At that time, Bākula responded from within the cauldron.
The father then took him out, and he was as intact as before.
Later, the mother went to the bank of a river.

original: 彼薄拘羅牽衣隨後。🔽母大瞋忿而作是言。
analyzed: 彼薄拘羅牽衣隨後。 母大瞋忿而作是言。
translated: Bākula pulled at her clothes and followed behind her.

He brought it to the market and put it on display for sale.

From morning until evening, it was about to rot and stink.

Seeing the large fish, he thought,
The flesh of this fish is very much.
It is about to rot and stink, and the price is very low.
I should buy it and take it home.
He then gave him money to buy fish and return home.
He immediately took a sharp knife and cut open the fish's belly.

original: 時薄拘羅在魚腹內高聲唱言。
analyzed: 時薄拘羅在魚腹內高聲唱言。
translated: At that time, Bakkula was inside the fish's belly, and he shouted loudly, saying,

He was content with few desires and always enjoyed quietude.
He had never taught others even a single four-line verse.
When the king heard this,
he sent someone to offer a single coin to this stupa.
The prime minister said to the king, He is also an arhat.
Why offer only a single coin to him?
The king said to his minister,
Because he only saved himself and was unable to transform others.
The stupa spirit did not accept it and returned it to the king.
The prime minister said,
He truly has few desires.
He does not even want to accept a single coin.
How much more so for many?
Thus, these five hundred great arhats
all have their own causes and conditions, but they are omitted here.

original: 阿恕伽王供養如來聲聞塔竟。

analyzed: 設百千祀　　方得為人　　我今便為
translated: Even if one performs a hundred thousand sacrifices, one may only become a human. I now immediately

analyzed: 不空受生　　遇良福田　　具造勝業

analyzed: 以危脆財　　而修堅法　　我所起塔
translated: Using impermanent and fragile wealth, I cultivate the firm Dharma. The stūpas I have built

analyzed: 嚴閻浮提　　猶如白雲　　莊校虛空

He went to the Bodhi tree and said this:
I now wish to create two kinds of blessings.

original: 一以千瓶盛滿香湯灌菩提樹。
analyzed: 一以千瓶盛滿香湯灌菩提樹。
translated: First, with a thousand jars filled with fragrant water, I will bathe the Bodhi tree.
Second, I will establish a great assembly.
I will then bathe myself and put on new clean clothes.
I will go up to a tall building and bow to the four directions.
And I will say this:
I wish all the noble ones will accept my invitation.

original: 適語已訖十方羅漢飛空而來。
analyzed: 適語已訖十方羅漢飛空而來。
translated: As soon as he finished speaking, arhats from the ten directions flew through the air and came.
There were twenty thousand holy people in three groups,
who also gathered like clouds.
They left the seat for the most senior monk, but no one dared to sit on it.
The king asked the monks,
Why is this empty seat left here?
Yasha answered,
There is a great arhat named Pindola,

original: 如來所記能師子吼威德高勝。
analyzed: 如來所記能師子吼威德高勝。
translated: who was prophesied by the Tathagata to be able to roar like a lion with lofty and majestic virtue.
He will come now.
When the king heard this, his body hair stood on end,
like an utpala flower just beginning to bloom.
He immediately joined his palms, looked up, and waited.
At that time, Pindola and the other arhats,
like a flock of geese, flew down from the sky.
The entire assembly rose in respect.

original: 王見尊者眉髮秀白身體相好如辟支佛。
analyzed: 王見尊者眉髮秀白身體相好如辟支佛。
translated: The king saw that the venerable one's eyebrows and hair were snow-white, and his bodily characteristics were like those of a pratyekabuddha.
He immediately bowed, prostrating his whole body to the ground,
and asked, Great Sage,
Have you seen the Tathāgata?
He replied, Yes, I have seen him.
His complexion is like a golden mass, his face like a full moon.
His body is adorned with the thirty-two marks.
His voice is deep and wondrous, a great compassionate abode.
The king asked again,
Where did you see him?
The Venerable One replied,
In Rājagṛha.
During the summer retreat,
I saw there the supreme field of merit.
Moreover, you once offered soil to the Buddha.
When the Buddha prophesied for you, I also got to see it.

original: 爾時彼王以國所有妻子眷屬金銀琉璃牛羊田宅。
analyzed: 爾時彼王以國所有妻子眷屬金銀琉璃牛羊田宅。
translated: At that time, the king offered all the possessions of the country, his wife and children, relatives, gold, silver, lapis lazuli, cattle, sheep, fields, houses,
and even his own body, palace ladies, and concubines,
to the Saṃgha.
He requested that his name be chanted and a ganacakra feast be held.

original: 灌菩提樹後自斟酌為僧行食。
analyzed: 灌菩提樹後自斟酌為僧行食。
translated: After the Bodhi tree was sprinkled with water, he personally served food to the Saṃgha.

The king said, Great Sage,
ghee is hard to digest, won't it cause illness?
The Venerable One replied,
It will not cause harm.
Why is this?
When the Buddha was in the world, water was the same as ghee now.
Therefore, eating it will never cause illness.
At that time, the Venerable one wanted to verify this matter.

original: 申手入地下至四萬二千餘里。
analyzed: 申手入地下至四萬二千餘里。
translated: He reached down to the ground and went down more than 42,000 li.
He then took the soil's fat and showed it to the king.
The king should now know.

original: 眾生薄福肥膩之味皆流入地。
analyzed: 眾生薄福肥膩之味皆流入地。
translated: Because sentient beings have little blessings, the flavors of fat and oil all flow into the ground.
Therefore, the blessings in the world gradually decline.
After the king made offerings, he joyfully withdrew.
The king had a younger brother.
Named Sudatta.
His wrong views were rampant and he hated śramaṇas.
The king used skillful means to make him change his wrong mind.
He immediately went forth and attained the path of arhatship.
Later, he was killed by a Qiang man.
At that time, the assembly asked Upagupta.
For what reason was that Sudatta
born into a wealthy family but killed by a Qiang man?
The Venerable one replied,
Listen well and I shall explain.
In the distant past, during the time of Buddha Kasyapa,
he had once made offerings to the Sangha.

original: 由斯福故生生常處尊榮富貴。
analyzed: 由斯福故生生常處尊榮富貴。
translated: Due to this merit, he was always born in a noble and wealthy family.
Moreover, in a past life, he was a hunter.
He set up nets but did not catch any birds.
Seeing a pratyekabuddha, he became angry.
He then used a sharp sword to behead it.
Because of this karma, he fell into the great hells.
He was always killed by others.
